Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Quality Talk Professional Development to Enhance Professional Vision and Leadership for STEM Teachers in High-Need Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project expands and augments a currently-funded NSF Noyce Track II teacher recruitment and retention grant with Quality Talk (QT), an innovative, scalable teacher-facilitated discourse model. It is hypothesized that the QT model will enhance pre- and in-service secondary teachers' development of professional vision and leadership skills necessary for 21st century STEM education. Over the course of four years, the work will address critical needs in physics and chemistry education in 10th through 12th grade classrooms in five of Georgia's high-need school districts by strengthening the capacity of participating teachers to design and implement lessons that support effective dialogic interactions. As a result of such interactions, students' scientific literacy will be enhanced, including their ability to participate in content-rich discourse (i.e., QT) through effective disciplinary critical-analytic thinking and epistemic cognition. The contributions of this project, beyond the tangible benefits for teacher and student participants, include the development, refinement, and dissemination of an effective QT intervention and professional developmental framework that the entire science education community can use to promote scientific literacy and understanding.

The project goals are being achieved through a series of three studies employing complementary methods and data sources, and a focus upon dissemination of the model in the final project year. The first two years of the project focus on developing and refining the curricular and intervention efficacy materials using design-based research methods. In Year 3, the project engages in a quasi-experimental study of the refined QT model, followed by further refinements before disseminating the materials both within Georgia and throughout the national science education community in Year 4. Quantitative measures of teacher and student discourse and knowledge, as well as video-coding and qualitative investigations of intervention efficacy, are being analyzed using multiple methods. In collaboration with, but independent from project staff and stakeholders, the participatory and responsive evaluation utilizes a variety of qualitative and quantitative methods to conduct formative and summative evaluation.

Over the course of four years, the project will involve the participation of approximately 32 teachers in Georgia whose students include substantive percentages from populations underrepresented in the STEM fields. In addition to advancing their own students' scientific literacy, these participating teachers receive professional development on how to train other teachers, outside of the project, in using QT to promote scientific literacy. Further, the project will conduct a QT Summit for educational stakeholders and non-participant teachers to disseminate the intervention and professional development model. Finally, the project team will disseminate the findings widely to applied and scholarly communities through a website with materials and PD information (http://www.qualitytalk.org), professional journals, conferences, and NSF's DRK-12 Resource Network. This project, with its focus on teacher leadership and the pedagogical content knowledge necessary to use discourse to promote student science literacy, significantly advances the nation's goals of producing critical consumers and producers of scientific knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant was designed to provide teachers and students with the training, support, and materials they need to achieve 21st century STEM education and scientific literacy goals. Modern curricular reform in science (e.g., A Framework for K-12 Science Education: Practices, Crosscutting Concepts, and Core Ideas, NRC, 2012; The Next Generation Science Standards, NGSS Lead States, 2013) has called for a shift toward student scientific literacy as a critical education outcome, away from the mere memorization of scientific facts and formulas. Traditional lecture and basic experimental procedure pedagogies are not sufficient to build deep student understanding, nor do they help students acquire the practices necessary for scientific literacy. Research has shown that such literacy requires more powerful pedagogies, such as incorporating meaningful scientific discourse into the classroom as a tool to explore and understand complex phenomena. Unfortunately, the pedagogical content knowledge necessary to implement such pedagogies is often not taught in teacher preparation programs. Therefore, we worked to develop, implement, and test Quality Talk (QT) Science, an innovative, scalable, teacher-led discourse model with empirical evidence of efficacy, in a high-school science classroom context. QT Science provided teachers with the professional development opportunities and materials, as well as on-going coaching and support, they needed to implement powerful and effective scientific discourse in their high-school chemistry and physics classrooms.

Using a quasi-experimental design, we tested the efficacy of QT Science professional development support, materials and coaching. QT Science included both empirically-supported instructional materials to teach and support authentic and high-quality student discourse as well as 21st century science lessons co-developed with practicing teachers. We found that QT Science led to changes in both teachers’ and students’ discourse practices. Teachers were able to more effectively teach and promote discourse focused upon substantive questions about core scientific phenomena as well as elaborative and appropriately critical responses to those questions. Importantly, students were better able to enact these discourse practices on their own, without teacher support, after QT Science discourse lessons. Over the span of an academic year, students asserted greater autonomy and control over the discourse, and produced more critical-analytic thinking and argumentation via their discussions. In turn, students who experienced QT Science produced stronger written arguments, a key indicator of scientific literacy.

Given the success of our research, we focused on disseminating our work on Quality Talk (QT) to the academic and practice science education communities. Our work has been published in top education and science education journals and presented at international conferences. We have manualized QT Science, making it available to educators. In addition, we held a QT Summit that involved over 20 middle- and high-school science teachers from the Pennsylvania State University area. Main topics included an overview of QT, how teachers could incorporate QT into their STEM lessons and classroom discourse, techniques for analyzing QT discourse including how to use those analyses to improve their teaching, and finally a presentation on systems-based modeling to design science and engineering research projects. Teachers received continuing education credits for their participation. Many teachers affirmed that new standards and goals for science education have proven challenging to implement in classrooms, and that they benefitted from additional professional development on teaching, facilitating, and analyzing scientific argumentation and discourse.

The research conducted for this grant will help to inform the next generation of scholarship on student discourse, including how to help educators effectively teach and support it, as well as how to leverage that discourse to achieve 21st century educational goals such as scientific literacy. One critical aspect of QT Science is that it is teacher-led with a clear, feasible implementation. Our findings, materials, manualization, and professional development efforts show great promise for scaling up QT Science within and across science education contexts, with the next steps involving implementation in other K-12 science settings and pre-service teacher preparation programs.
